sentences.sentence: And every kind of delicious food was cooked for poor Hansel, while Grethel got nothing but crab-shells.
Each morning the old woman visited the little stable( 马厩 ), and cried,
“Hansel, put out your finger, that I may tell if you are fat enough yet.”
Hansel, however, used to hold out a little bone( 骨头 ).
The old woman, who had weak eyes, could not see what it was.
She thought it was Hansel’s finger, and was very surprised that he wasn’t getting fatter.
When four weeks had passed and Hansel seemed to remain so thin, she lost patience and could wait no longer.
“Now then, Grethel,” cried she to the little girl; “be quick and get some water. Whether Hansel be fat or thin, tomorrow I must kill and cook him.”
Oh, what a terrible thing for the poor little sister to have to fetch( 取来 ) water to cook her brother!
How the tears( 眼泪 ) flowed( 流 ) down over her cheeks( 脸颊 )!
“Dear God, please help us!” cried she; “if we had been eaten by wild animals in the wood, at least we should have died together.”
“Do not waste your crying and complaining( 诉说（痛苦） ) on me,” said the old woman; “why should I care?”
Early next morning Grethel had to get up, make the fire, and fill the cooking pot( 锅 ).
“First we will do the baking( 烘烤 ),” said the old woman; “I have heated the oven( 烤炉 ) already, and kneaded( 揉 ) the dough( 生面团 ).”
She pushed poor Grethel toward the oven, out of which the flames( 火焰 ) were already shining.
“Look inside,” said the witch( 女巫 ), “and see if it is hot enough to bake the bread.”
And once Grethel was in, she meant to shut the door upon her and bake Grethel, and then eat her when she was fully cooked.
But Grethel saw through( 识破 ) the witch’s plan, and said,
“I don’t know how to do it; how can I see if it is hot enough?”
“Stupid girl,” said the old woman, “the opening is big enough, do you see? I could get in myself!” and she bent down( 弯腰 ) and put her head in the oven’s mouth.
Then Grethel gave her a push, so that she went in farther, and she shut the iron door upon her, and closed it with the iron bar( 门闩 ) that went across.
Oh, how frightfully( 可怕地 ) the witch screamed( 尖叫 )!
But Grethel ran away, and left the wicked( 邪恶的 ) witch to burn to death.
Grethel went straight to Hansel, opened the stable door, and cried,
“Hansel, we are free! The old witch is dead!”
Then out came Hansel like a bird from its cage( 笼子 ) as soon as the door is opened.
How happy they were!
How they fell on each other’s neck and hugged( 拥抱 ) each other, and danced, and kissed each other!
And as they had nothing more to fear, they searched the old witch’s house from top to bottom, and found a chest( 箱子 ) of pearls( 珍珠 ) and precious( 珍贵的 ) stones.
“This is something better than pebbles( 鹅卵石 )!” said Hansel, as he filled his pockets.
And Grethel, thinking she would also like to carry something home with her, filled her apron( 围裙 ) full.
“Now, away we go,” said Hansel; “if we only can get out of the witch’s wood.”
When they had journeyed a few hours they came to a large river.
“We can never get across this,” said Hansel. “I see no stepping-stones and no bridge.”
“And there is no boat either,” said Grethel; “but here comes a white duck. If I ask her, she will help us over.” So she cried,
“Duck, duck, here we stand,
Hansel and Grethel, on the land,
Stepping-stones and bridge we lack
Carry us over on your white back.”
And the duck came when she was called, and Hansel got upon her, and told his sister to come too.
“No,” answered Grethel, “that would be too hard for the duck. We can go separately, one after the other.”
And that was how they got across.
After that they went on happily, until the way grew more and more familiar( 熟悉的 ), and at last they saw their father’s house, far off in the distance.
Then they ran up to it, rushed in at the door, and hugged their father.
The man had not had a peaceful hour since he left his children in the wood; but the wife was dead.
And when Grethel opened her apron, the pearls and precious stones she had carried were scattered( 散开 ) all over the floor, and Hansel took one handful after another out of his pocket.
Then all their worries were over, and they lived in great joy( 愉快 ) together.

article_info.previous: 鸟儿们把Hansel丢在路上的面包屑吃掉了，Hansel和Grethel找不到回家的路。在一只小鸟的带领下，Hansel和Grethel来到由蛋糕和糖果造成的小屋前，饥肠辘辘的Hansel和Grethel开心地吃了起来。就在这时，一个老妇人走了出来，慈祥的老妇人居然是邪恶的女巫，Hansel和Grethel能安全离开吗？
article_info.share_words: When four weeks had passed and Hansel seemed to remain so thin, she lost patience and could wait no longer.

question.cn: 女巫是真的想要烤面包吗？
question.en: Did the witch really want to bake the bread?

analysis: 文中提到：“And once Grethel was in, she meant to shut the door upon her and bake Grethel, and then eat her when she was fully cooked.”女巫真正的目的是烤Grethel，因此答案选B。

question.cn: 在搜寻了女巫的房子后，他们发现了什么？
question.en: What did they find after they searched the old witch’s house?

analysis: 文中提到：“And as they had nothing more to fear, they searched the old witch’s house from top to bottom, and found a chest of pearls and precious stones.”因此答案选C。

question.en: How did they get across the river?

options.en: They got across the river by boat.
They swam to cross the river.

options.cn: 一只鸭子帮助他们过河。
options.en: A duck helped them cross the river.

analysis: 文中提到：“And the duck came when she was called, and Hansel got upon her, and told his sister to come too. “No,” answered Grethel, “that would be too hard for the duck. We can go separately, one after the other.” And that was how they got across.”因此答案选C。
